I've been sitting a number of children lately, and the most recent additions to the rotation have been J (6) and A (4). 

I've been walking to the school to pick them up and take them home. What is a 20 minute walk by myself is, of course, a 45 minute walk with the little ones. Everything fascinates them. We've got to stop and take a look, make up a story about it, and then have a fierce debate about who has the better *insert object or physical attribute* before we can continue the trek home. Factor in the snow that they must walk in, and that one stride of theirs being equal to about two of mine, and we're moving like molasses. I *could* drive, I suppose, but that would also mean that I have to wait in the horrid line that circles around the parking lot in front and spills out into the two lane street. I don't mind the walking too much anyway. It's good to be out and walking, and the cold isn't nearly as piercing when you have chattering and skipping charges to not lose.

J. Ah, J. The girl is dramatic and has a wild imagination that my logical side, even as a child, has never been able to fully get behind. She is the firm belief that all her stuffed animals are real. Do not attempt to refer to them as inanimate objects or you will be told what's what with a scowl. I guess I don't blame her, what with not having the option of anything other than a fish for a house pet. I do see little bits of myself peeking through in her, though. As much as I would like to pretend that I was always the way I am now,there are too many home movies depicting a dramatic chatter bug to say that I was anything else.

She said something really funny, or at least something I found funny, on our walk home from school the other day. We were walking back with another little girl that lives in the building, and J was lifting her up and over the little puddles of water that had pooled from the melting snow. Once we parted ways, she looked up at me and said, "Did you see how I was pretending with N that the puddles were lakes? Pretending stuff like that makes their childhood more magical." The darnedest things, right? I had to keep myself from laughing. I suppose she's right, after a fashion, but it's not quite something I had expect to hear.

At the age of six, J knows how to work the system. I get the strong feeling that both children have been rather coddled, but J, she knows how to really work it. The moment that disappointment looms on the horizon, her face starts to crumple, her voice slides a few octaves up the scale into a whine, and the water works are deployed. This act is immediately reversed if the alternative is something that benefits her. To be honest, I enjoy denying her the things she wants. Not because of the impending tantrum and how funny it is, and it really is funny, but because disappointment builds character and appreciation for what you do have.I imagine my parents felt the same way when they did it to me, necessary or not. I may have not been back then, but I'm thankful for it now. My favorite requests that I've denied so far have been to go to Starbucks for chocolate milk, and to have more of my "delicious delicious" cookies.  

A is my favorite of the pair. I am sure there are many valid reasons as to why this is the case, but the biggest is probably because he's not nearly as dramatic and temperamental as J. I was lucky to have some one on one time with him, two days in a row, last week. He came over the first day, and searching for activities, we made fresh smoothies and peanut butter cookies. That was the best thing ever.The whole time I was reminded of the a young plucky duck and his desperate need to push the button. After lots and lots of "Now? Can I push it now?", A was beside himself with excitement and laughter when he got to push the button and the thing whirred to life. The whole scene was pretty fantastic.  The day after that he came over and we made smoothies again and my flax bread, which we then ate in peanut butter sandwiches. I don't know how wise it was to make smoothies two days in a row though, as he's been fixated on having more. I'm happy to make the smoothies for us, there isn't anything better that I could possibly give the kid, but I'm running dangerously low on fruit! I started telling him no today. It'll do him good, and I have fruit for breakfast. ;)

I also really enjoy having A around because he has really had fun helping me make food goods. Man, can the boy crack an egg! We were making the peanut butter cookies the first night and he asked if he could crack the egg. I figured what the heck, and let him give it a shot. Goodness gracious, I was surprised that we had a beautifully cracked egg! I've let him crack all the eggs since then, and he's a total wiz at it. 

Both little beings are fun in their own ways, but this sibling equation has me seeing another set of children, two years apart in age. Of course, the roles are switched, but I see myself and my older brother in A and J. It's been simultaneously hard, and therapeutic to be there to act as a mediator. On the one hand, it's hard not to hear the mean words that she says and imagine that my older brother is saying them to me. On the other, perhaps this is my opportunity to help forge a healthier bond between this brother and sister.

Each child has taken to Souki differently. J, like most girls that age, loves both Souki and Mapetite, who we haven't seen much of incidentally. She will suddenly break out of concentration on whatever she is doing and will beg to go and check on (pet, play with, draw, let out) the dog. I let her. I don't care, and the dog gets attention. I wouldn't mind letting Souki out to walk around and do what she likes per usual, but then there's A. He's about 80% terrified of her. It makes sense really, seeing as how they are about the same size and level. It also doesn't help her case that she really loves little kids, and that she smiles. Souki does this when she gets really excited. The moment that starts, she bares her teeth, which in turn crinkles up her snout. She will lay her ears back and walk towards you like a slinky weasel, tail turning like a windmill. The closer she gets to her target, and the more attention that target gives her in return, the more she will start to prance like a bridled pony. It is a sight to behold. I can certainly see why that would frighten a 4 year old, even if she is a super sweet girl. I usually have to corral the dog into some area with a baby gate so that A can relax. Having Souki couped up simply kills J as she feels that the dog doesn't have enough room to move about. Whenever we need to go into the area that Sou is in, A begs for a piggy back ride and clings to me with a frozen death grip, body ridged and prepared for anything. Giggles, squeals, and shouts of "no" escape him if the dog comes too close in the effort to try to sniff his feet. Hopefully they can become friends soon.

Something that kind of concerns me is the television. It is an amazingly powerful thing, and I hadn't fully realized just what a weapon it is. The last few times that J and A have been over, we've watched some Wallace and Gromit shows. The credits start rolling, the music starts playing, and they are lost. I can ask the same question four times before I get an answer. I don't know what else there is to say, other than that I think the t.v. will be something used only when absolutely needed. Thank you, Crayola, for the free printable coloring pages and activities!

A handful of trail mix cannot be simply thrown in the mouth and eaten. There is a certain mathematical equation to the perfect flavor combination. These little piles of flavor within a pile of flavor are each to be savored in their own right. There may be too many almonds in the handful you just grabbed. Are you going to sit there and resign yourself to the fact that it's not an amazing combination, one simply filling the need for something to munch on? Will you take the time to pair each almond with another nut, a raisin and some kind of chocolate to achieve the flavor explosion that it was intended to be?

Perhaps it all ends up in the same place, but to me, that lends to a mentality that is dangerous. If you consume your food in a blur without the slightest enjoyment, stuffing your gullet with an anxiety riddled mentality that if you don't eat it quickly there will be no more, it hints that you have the same mentality when approaching life. Eat it quickly, gorge yourself, and then it's over. Did you even taste it? Where is the satisfaction and fulfillment in a rushed, and glutinous existence? One filled with the materialistic desires that we're told that we want and need for happiness. I don't want to play that game anymore, always hungering for unimportant goals and possessions. What is gained by accumulation? By my assessment, using objects to fill the void will only make you feel more empty, no matter how shiny that new top of the line computer is. Enrichment of the mind and soul is the key to fulfillment. I'd wished I'd known that years ago.

For now, I will just enjoy my trail mix, one thought out bite at a time, and we'll see where that takes me.

Ah shit. Here we are again with another update. You know, I always find myself being faced with the problem of never having anything I'm motivated to write about. I mean, I've got so many different trains of thought, many of which run at the same time, and all the extra bits constantly whirring and spinning around in my head throughout the course of the day, that by the time I get around to sitting down to write about what I had seen as brilliant earlier that day, I'm just so exhausted with the subject that I have no motivation. I blame my over active brain for being the reason that I don't post often. 

So, I've been doing quite a lot of... well, self discovery over the last year or so. Realizing the cause to the effect of why you are who you are is a feeling mixed of both beguilement and melancholy. I guess that was the easy part though. The hard part is figuring out how to deal with what you've got, and finding out how to change it for the better. I've been struggling with the things I've learned about myself. In fact, I feel like the closer I come to understanding myself, the more I am left feeling bereft of any idea as to how to cope. I've considered going to a counselor or some unbiased third party to talk all of this through with, but that's gonna have to wait until next year when the cash flow starts up again. Yeah, I know I've got a few people that would be more than willing to jump at the opportunity to listen ;) but there are some things that you just can't tell anyone else but a stranger. It makes for a more freeing admission without all the judgment when you run into them later. I must admit that this would be the first time that I have actually wanted to go to a counselor of any kind of my own volition. Funny how so much changes with age. 

You know, it's funny to look at one's parents and analyze them a little bit too. Let's take my mother for example. God knows I love her and she means well with most everything she does, but I would have to nominate her for the Denial award. She's tried so hard not to be her mother and has been so vocal about how she hopes to hell that she never becomes her that she won't allow herself to see that she is really closer than she thinks. For the last 5+ years my mother has been of the very strong opinion that my grandmother is a narcissist. While she may be correct in her assessment of my grandmother's consumption with herself, I've come to see it as her subconscious attempt to distract from her own, albeit a different brand, narcissism. She'll never admit it, because 1) she's the stereotypical woman who never admits that they are at fault or have flaws, and 2)... well, the first reason covers the bulk of it really. My mother's flavor is medical narcissism, constantly dwelling and talking about what new issue she's dealing with and then lecturing at length as to what she found in the way of information on the internet. I can understand that she has a reason to be looking for her own information on the internet, considering her constant health problems and the system not really putting it's neck out there to help you all that much these days, but there has to be a line that determines the necessary from the obsessive. Shit, if I even mention that I haven't been feeling well or have a certain symptom, she'll go out and fill my inbox with a hundred different links on the subject, many of which are just playing the broken record. Perhaps she likes finding all this information, but I, for one, find that it does nothing but give me anxiety about shit I may or may not have, with the end result being that I had something totally different. I've gotten to a point where all the other accumulated shit in life has got me so wound up and strung tight that I just can't take anymore stress than is absolutely necessary, so I've just taken to deleting the emails without even reading them. I want to tell her to just bugger off when it comes to this shit, but she always gets so bent out of shape that it's easier just to not say anything. Anyway.

Speaking of my mother, I'm hosting the family Thanksgiving/Christmas gathering this year. It's a step out of the ordinary to have our family Christmas anywhere other than the parent's and at Christmas time, but it's always such a hassle to get everyone together and have a relaxed time, and I am not eager to drive home again any time soon. :P My brother and his wife also adopted a beagle a few months back, and considering my mom's "no dogs in the house" policy, it makes sense to have it where the dogs can be indoors. So, early December everyone is coming out this way to have our gathering here. I'm excited yet anxious all at the same time. Considering my mothers sensitivity to anything that smells, it could be a total nightmare. Just about every single attempt at a family vacation has ended up with us hotel hopping to find one that was "safe" and not really being able to enjoy anything because there was always the stress and fear that there would be some new problem to deal with just around the corner. I've been painting the walls to cover the old smoke smells in the walls from when Rannell smoked, and it's been working fairly well I guess, although it's going to be necessary to steam clean the carpets and switch over to everything unscented a month before they arrive. Regardless of what happens, no one can say that I didn't give it a damn good effort.

I've felt a bit socially starved lately. Makes sense seeing as how my human interaction has been majorly limited to Rannell and my work family. I've got two friends north of Chitown, but as everyone knows, things have been tight and you don't drive if you don't have to. It's been pretty lonely to be honest. Mathieu has been gone for a year now and at this point it's pretty much indefinite. Without him there, there's a great sense of loss. There's always the feeling like you have something really amusing you want to tell your best friend, and you look over expecting them to be there, because they had been for a long time, and coming to remember that there's nothing there anymore but an empty seat. I'm very sad to see him go but I know he's doing what he needs to and I can't fault him. 

Well, I think that's all I can muster for one evening. It's definitely time to hit the hay.

Man. It's been awhile. I couldn't tell you where the time has gone, except that I don't have a lot to show for it that I can be proud of. Don't get me wrong, I've had my accomplishments like the dog being alive and somewhat trained, I just haven't accomplished what I'd hoped I would.

To play a little catch up, I quit the "bakery" job that I had. I won't ever regret that decision, simply because it was the most poisonous environment that I've ever been in, but it's proven to be the harder path to travel. After I left there I decided that I wanted to take a break from pastry, feeling tainted from my previous experience. I went and worked for a vet clinic for awhile, but that was really quite the joke of a job. I went in thinking that I'd be in some kind of secretarial position, but that never ended up happening and I got stuck poking dogs with needles and blah blah blah. Nothing happened the way my employers said it would in regards to my position, and it just ended up being a weird situation. After that there was a brief stint at a t-shirt company here, but due to health issues and it being a seasonal position, they didn't really decide to keep me on after the sale. I can't blame them, it never looks good when you're out sick with the flu for a week, and even worse when the seasonal job only lasts for five-ish weeks. Between each job there's been a period of maybe three months or so where I've been unemployed, and crikey.. it's been no walk in the park. You know, I'd love to have a great and amazing job that would allow me to have three months off at a time to do traveling or whatever, but when it's under the circumstances of unemployment, it's bleak and depressing. Right now I'm on the down swing again and mixed with the weather, and being sick all the damn time, it's really got me down in the dumps. I've had enough money to just make ends meet, but I've gotten to the end of that safe net and it's made everything just that much more daunting.

I don't know what to say though about the whole job thing.. I'm kinda lost. Pastry seems to have lost all it's appeal to me as a profession and yet if you asked me what I wanted to really do with my life, I'd probably stand there with my mouth gaping like a fish out of water. Sure, I have things that drive me and that I love doing, but shit... let's look at the possibilities. Most anything requires you to have some education and a degree of some sorts, I mean, at least if you're wanting a career from it. I honestly wouldn't mind going back to school, but learning from my last flop of a life decision, I've not jumped in head first. I'm also hesitant to shell out more money when I've got no direction and a mountain of debt already. I've tried taking those stupid personality tests to see where I would best be suited, and I've tried talking to the career counselors at the college, but no one seems to really have the time for you unless you're plight will put the cash in their pocket. I really an truly want and know that I need a job. I want that sense of usefulness again, a steady schedule, and the start of cash flow again is always wonderful.. it's just a struggle when you are floundering and sick.

While my life hasn't necessarily been the busiest one ever, the past year has been a blur. Looking back, I spent just about fifty percent of the time sick. The news has reported that this year has been the worst flu season in American history, and I must have been lucky enough to get hit each time it came round, to then deal with the bronchitis aftermath. Now that I'm finally over the flu for the third time, I find myself back in the doctor's office and having a flash back to junior year of high school. I would have bet anything that I had ulcers, but thanks to modern advancements, we've ruled that out and are still on the road to figuring this shit out. The newest theory is gallstones. It's been pretty terrible to tell the truth. I've lost over 20 pounds in the last month and a half, I've had no energy to speak of and I can't stand up for any real period of time without being overwhelmingly nauseous. My entire stomach area feels like I've swallowed a super nova and it's trying to find it's way out of the front of my tummy. Pain in my stomach and pelvis area are pretty much the daily norm now. *Sigh* I tell ya.. it's really tiring to always be sick with one thing or another and having all these ridiculous problems when you're only just beginning to explore your twenties. I guess that's the only upside to not having a job at the moment. I don't have an employer to disappoint.

**Update** Well, it wasn't gallstones. You know, I don't want to have anything to be wrong with me, but most of me really really wants them to finally find something, if only for the fact that if they find what the problem is, something can be done to treat it so I'm not in pain all the fucking time. Also, due to douche bag doctors the first go around, I've switched to someone else and we're working on a new theory. It's a really nice thing having a doctor that doesn't think you're crazy or making shit up.

Considering all circumstances, I honestly don't know how Rannell puts up with me sometimes. I count myself really lucky though. Hell.. he's been more supportive than I could hope anyone to be, and I'm so grateful to him for that. Part of me sometimes feels like he's so good to me that I just don't measure up, although I try my damnedest to show him every day that I love him and that I appreciate what he does for me. I'm so happy with him and what we have together, and let me tell ya kids, this may just be the real McCoy. Rannell and the girls are by far the most positive contributors to my life, and are my reason for getting up in the morning. We've actually been talking about our future together and about our plans to get married. I'm really excited and can't wait. Now, while the large picture perfect wedding is what most woman dream about for their whole lives, I can't help but be attracted to the idea of just having a small intimate wedding and then something more special for the honeymoon. Who knows though, I may end up wanting "every girls dream" after all.

Well, I think it's time to wind this up. It's taken me almost a week to write just this and I'm losing all motivation to keep adding. Hey, thanks for stopping by.

~J

Or how about seeing him get his head bashed in with the same sledge hammer as he lays on the floor and begs for his life? Well guess what! You can now see said things happen in this movie! I have to say that I think I have a pretty steady stomach for violence, and that I can take a lot of blood and guts, but this movie was almost too much to  handle.

OH! Let's not forget that the Bears are going to the Superbowl! You know, I honestly can say that I have gained a new appreciation for football and it's... related activities. I do have to laugh about it though.. it's funny timing for me to start liking it at the end of the damn season. I guess there is always next year to get more into it. 

For now though, it's time for me to go make dinner and keep Rannell from throwing the Wii remote into the t.v. because he can't get past this one level. Oh what fun ^_^

So this morning I got up and went about my business of getting my cereal made and such. I was in the kitchen and I was listening and there was a kinda scratching sound. I really didn't think too much about it because I had heard it before and I guess I thought it was just the flies buzzing around behind the stove. The cats had been chasing them around. Anyway. I got up and went towards the bathroom to wash my face and I heard the shuffling behind the stove. I thought to myself 'damn it one of the cats got back there and must be stuck'. So I look back there and see a little movement. I can't see much because it's dark but I call both cats names and neither one answers. I thought to myself 'they must just be scared' so I got Willow to get her flash light just to make sure the cat was back there because I didn't want to move the stove for no reason. Low and behold, there wasn't a cat back behind the stove, but a fucking squirrel. No idea how it got in the house, and no idea how long it had been back there, but it was. I am going to bet it was for at least a day or two because the cats have been stalking the  stove and that corner of the kitchen for a few days now. And here I thought it was flies. ;) Willow and I went right to work finding boxes and getting the broom and we scared it into the box. It was funny, not because we were screaming or being pansy girls like most would. It was funny because of how calm we were and the conversation we were having while catching the little sneak. So today I was encountered with someone that lost their pet. She told me about it and I was amazed at how well she was handling it. I don't accept loss well. I am the kind of person that finds a sick bunny and tries to do something for it. If it is lost, then it breaks my heart and I cry. Yeah, I cry for some creature that I didn't even know for more than an hour. I am and have always been one of those kids who has little burials for them too. It just feels right that way. I have lost so many things in my life time and have super glued my heart back together with each loss. I am amazed each time I mend it because the shards get smalled and smaller each time. Is it possible to just.. I don't know.. sweep it up into a pile of dust and roll it up in a ball of Duct-tape? I mean.. they say that fixes everything right?

One of my losses that I grieve most, other than the loss of the best person in the entire world (my Grandma Great), was my pet lamb named Violet. Let me begin by telling you why the hell I would have a lamb at my house. 

My dad grew up on a farm, and being the farmboy that he is/was and seeing how he is a vet, we had animals. Yeah, sheep and cows and wonderful crap like that. He rented out farm space from some lady so he could keep them. It was winter time and a ewe had given birth to a lamb. Just so happens that there was a goat that had two kids too. So he brought them home so they could sit under a heat lamp on the patio. I was instantly attached to those animals. I would spend hours sitting there with them.. just talking to them, because that's what little girls do, and I would much rather have a live animal versus the stupid plastic barbies. I would take them out into the back yard and 
run around with them, but Violet.. she was different. You know the song 'Mary had a little lamb'? That was me and Violet. I think that because I spent so much time with them they thought I was their mom. She would follow me everywhere. I can't remember why, but I would walk around with one of those plastic rods that you see on window blinds.. the one that makes them shut and open. I think I would pretend it was my walking stick or something. Anyway. I was tickled pink at the prospect that I had such a cute little lamb that would follow me. I even walked over to the neighbors house with her in tow just to show them how happy I was. 

Finally the day came that they were strong enough to go back to the farm and be introduced back into the herd. I was really sad when that happened, but the fact that my dad was always taking us out there to train, so I was content with seeing her there. Eventually she was sent to another farm so my dad's friends could work with her.

One night I was sitting on the couch and talking with my mom and helping her with my little brother when my brother walks in the door. He runs up to me, puts his face in mine and yells 'YOUR LAMB IS DEAD!! YOUR LAMB IS DEAD!!' I thought it was all a joke.My brother has always been cruel so it wouldn't have been anything new from him. I looked at my dad waiting for him to calm my fears and tell me that Matt was just being mean. But what I saw in his face was not reassurance.. but truth. It was real. Every word of it. I cried and cried and could barely hear what my dad said. She has broken her leg and it got really infected. She died from it. I was so utterly heart broken for something so sweet and gentle. I have hated my brother for doing what he did. He took the chance I had of getting it broken to me in a easier way. He stole that from me. 

Like I said.. we all lose things.. some of great importance, and others of lesser. They still all hurt and it still takes time to heal. I know what loss is. I have stared it in the face, and I have over come the pain each time. I wonder if there will ever be a day when it defeats me.

~Jessica

They never really liked me and the boys always teased me. The fact that I was always sick too didn't help my friends situation. 

Middle school and high school were pretty much the same thing. Except for one person. Mark. This kid is something else. He's just as quirky as I am and we have a blast together. I met him my freshman year in our English class. We never really talked much because we were both shy, but eventually by the end of the year, we were friends. Sophmore year was awesome because we had Biology class together and we were always in the same group. He sat right behind me so he would lean forward and I would lean back and we would fall asleep on eachother. Our Biology teacher must have liked us or never noticed, but she never said anything.. but she yelled at two kids for 'holding hands'. He was really just trying to warm up his friends hand but hey.. it's ok. :}He and I did so much together.. I wish there were more people like him out there. More people that want to be with me rather. :}

There must be something in the water because I am wanted everywhere else but here.

~Jessica

I am sitting here at 3 in the morning wondering why I am not in bed so I am rested for work tomorrow. For some reason I can't seem to care. I have had more than enough to make me happy, and I have been that.. really happy. It's a wonderful thing.

I have been listening to the most wonderful music lately. The Garden State soundtrack is awesome. The only way I can describe how great it is, is by telling you the feeling I get when I listen to it. 

When I put it on, I imagine that I am in a convertible car with the top down. It's night time and the air is warm and soft and caresses my skin like a silken hand. The only sounds are the music playing, the soft rush of wind as we cut through the night on an empty road, and the gentle purr of the engine. The smell of sweet rain that the patchy clouds promise would hang in the air with that soft rich smell of earth. The moon shines in all it's glory among the stars that swim in it's wake. 

This is the feeling I get when I listen to it. And this is not the only music that I get vivid images with. Another one is called Teardrop. With this song I am taken back to childhood. This is what I see.

I am back in my mothers lap, surrounded by her arms. She is rocking me while I have my ear pressed to her chest. I can hear the beat of her heart and the creek of the rocking chair as she rocks back and forth, along with the soft rustle while she slowly runs her hand over my ear and through my hair. The heat of her body calms me and lets me relax as I settle into her. She hums the tune of 'Edelweiss', which was and is my favorite song she would sing to me. I can smell the softness of her skin and the warmth of her makes it so much sweeter. The complete feeling of trust and safety is the only thing that I feel there in her lap, being held.

Thank you to that special someone that introduced me to these songs. You know who you are. Thank you for helping to give me such vivid images that I could almost swear I was there.

~Jessica
